thread.title: Girl asks police for help with maths homework, gets surprising response
thread.title_full: Girl asks police for help with maths homework, gets surprising response

author: Sophie Roberts
title: Girl asks police for help with maths homework, gets surprising response
text:
A PRIMARY school student reached out to the police for help on her maths homework — and we think their response was perfect even if their calculation wasn’t. 
Ten-year-old Lena Draper decided to reach out to the Marion Police Department on Facebook after getting stuck on the tricky questions, reports The Sun .
When Lena first contacted the police department, she was met with an automated response. Picture: Facebook Source: Supplied 
Instead of ignoring her request, Ohio officer Lieutenant B.J. Gruber did his best to lend a hand.
Lena informed the policeman that she was stuck on the problem (8+29)x15.
He quickly responded with the tip: “Do the numbers in the parenthesis first so in essence it would be 37×15.”
After nailing the advice for the first question, Lieutenant Gruber was given a more difficult task.
Lena asked him for the solution of (90+27)+(29+15)x2.
The officers hastily came to Lena’s rescue when she told them she was struggling with the work. Picture: Facebook Source: Supplied 
The confident officer responded with what he believed to be the correct answer, advising: “Take the answer from the first parenthesis plus the answer from the second parenthesis and multiply that answer times two.
“Work left to right doing the work inside the parenthesis first.”
But Facebook users were quick to notice that his maths solution didn’t quite add up.
They argued that to solve the problem, you add the numbers in the second parentheses and multiply them by two, before adding the digits in the first set of brackets.
Lieutenant Gruber (centre) was quick to respond to the baffled primary school student. Picture: Twitter. Source: Supplied 
Lena’s mum Molly posted a snap of the adorable exchange on to Facebook after her daughter revealed that the kind officer had been helping her out.
She told ABC news : “I didn’t believe her and asked for a screen shot. I thought it was pretty funny. And I love that they went ahead with it.
“I was happy, but not surprised that they responded so quickly. They are wonderful with their communication with the community.”
Sadly the second solution to Lena’s maths problem didn’t quite add up. Picture: Facebook Source: Supplied 
After Lieutenant Gruber was told about the mistake, he joked: “Hoping it is truly the thought that counts since apparently I cannot!
“Especially since the answer was wrong, it was very nice for Molly to acknowledge our attempt to help her daughter with some math homework.”
This article originally appeared on The Sun.
